KEN BROWN ON THE PGA CHAMPIONSHIP
The European Tour's flagship event, the PGA Championship, has attracted seven out of the world's top 15 golfers to play at the beautiful West Course at Wentworth.


One of those, world number five Ernie Els, lives on the Wentworth estate and he has been the mastermind behind the redesign of the West Course over the past two years.


The changes he has made have been widespread and the bunkers he has built for this year's tournament brings the total added to 36.


With the weather being so good, and the course so firm and fast, many players have fallen foul of Els's tweaks and the enlargement of the ditch on the 12th fairway has attracted its fair share of controversy.


There's a noticeable absence of players from the American Tour here, but their circuit is so strong that it's difficult to prise people away.


Englishman Justin Rose, though, is one that has returned from the States to play in Britain for the first time since 2004 and his first-round performance oozed class. 


A back injury has stopped him playing since his fifth place finish at the Masters in April, yet he has showed no ill effects or rustiness on the West Course so far.


Keep an eye on Ryder Cup hero Padraig Harrington, as the Irishman could be leaving the course a very happy man on Sunday.


His win at last week's Irish Open has given him the chance of scooping a one million Euro bonus if he can become the first player to win back-to-back in Ireland and then here at the PGA Championship.   


He wasn't at his best during his first round, but that often happens after you've just won as you can get fatigued with all the press conferences and attention.


But he battled through it and the signs seem good as his short game looked as world class as ever.


Enjoy the action,

Ken


Ken Brown is commentating for the BBC at Wentworth this weekend. During his playing career he competed in five Ryder Cups and won four times on the European Tour.
